MEMORANDUM BY THE.MINISTER ^Op HEALTH.I circulate herewith a. draft of the Rating and Valuation Jj," Bill. I realise that a Bill of this size and complexity will require some time for its proper consideration and acoo.rJdAngly I do not ask : the Home Affairs Committee to approve its final form at this stage, v But I am most anxious to give notice of introduction of tho Bill on Wednesday the Sth instant, and to- introduoe it formally on-Thursday the 9th, in which case the Bill can be read a seoond time soon after Easter but need not be circulated to the House until after the Recess.I therefore invite the Committee to give their approval now to the general principles of the Bill, postponing until their next meeting, which X hope can be held before Parliament reassembles, consideration of its details.Part I of the Bill deals with the reform of the rating system. These provisions will, I hope, command general support, particularly from the larger local authorities who have in many cases secured similar reforms by means of Private Sill legislation.Amongst other things it Is proposed to abolish parochial rating and thereby reduce the number of rating authorities from over 15,000 to under 2,000.The Clauses in Part II dealing with Valuation Areas and Authorities will be controversial, and we know will be bitterly opposed by the Poor Law Authorities. The proposal for a single valuation for rating and income tax purposes will Immediately simplify the procedure of the assessment authorities and will intro-duce uniformity of practice in place of the varying methods now prevailing. Without such uniformity it is impossible to formulate any practicable schemes for the settlement of the vexed question of the relations between national and local taxation, but there is likely to be some opposition from those who fear that the proposals will give undue power to the Inland Revenue Authorities.This part of the Bill also includes two important mattersnamely, -(1) Rating of Machinery, and(2) Valuation of Railways,The proposals in regard to the Rating of Maohinery are based, with certain important modifications, upon the recent report of the Inter-Departmental Committee. I propose to receive deputa-tions from representatives of the machinery users on the one hand and the local authorities on the other, and if it should appear that the draft proposals are not likely to receive sufficient support, I should be prepared, when the Bill reaches the Committee stage, either to amend them or to delete them from the Bill altogether.The Clauses relating to Valuation of Railways represent in effect an agreement reached between representatives of the Govem-ment Departments concerned, of the Railway Companies, and of the local authorities, and should, therefore, be mainly non-controversial.
